captions.text:
This the latest version of the Ford
Mondeo is a very
notable car in many different ways. First of all, the previous version

is a multiple award winner - it's picked up
countless What Car? awards

over the years. It is still a common
sight on UK roads, but we've been waiting

for a very long time for this version - the
first
concept car previewing this car appeared nearly three

years ago. The wait is finally nearly
over, though,
and here are the five key things that we know about this car so far.

The Ford Mondeo is a little bit of a
rarity in its class

in that a lot of its rivals predominately
come as saloons. For things like the Mazda,
the premium badge versions from Audi, BMW etc that's certainly the case.
Now there is going to be a saloon version of this, but you will only get that on
the hybrid version and on the really top-level trims, but most of the versions are going to
be, like this car,

hatchbacks and there's also an estate
version, which is going on sale
exactly the same time. Now one thing we've really been fond of at What Car?
in the past with the Mondeo is its sheer size and,

you can see just looking at it that's still going to be the case - it's a
massive car. The boot
is especially large - very wide and very deep.

This car gets a much higher level of
equipment from the previous Mondeos.

Now even the entry-level versions get
alloy wheels dual-zone air conditioning

the latest version at the Sync
entertainment system - we'll go into more detail
on that later.

The reason I'm sat back here talking about
equipment is these

seatbelts. They're actually air bag seat
belts, so they blow up like

air bags in the case of a crash, and
that is a really quite high level of equipment,

something that you otherwise only get on
things like the Mercedes S-class.

They are an option, but at just under
couple of hundred quid it might be a very
worthwhile option to consider.

One thing that Fords have been
criticised for quite a lot in the past
is this central console. They are often covered in buttons and are

really quite confusing, but this one
looks a lot cleaner and easier to

navigate around. There are still some
buttons down here but

they're largely for things like the climate
control and the heating.
Now, there's a couple other buttons here but that's about it. Most things are controlled through
this
eight-inch touchscreen as standard. You also get Ford's latest Sync system - that
brings

DAB digital radio on every model,
Bluetooth and,
on the higher levels, sat nav. Many Mondeos have been bought with diesel engines for
long treks

up and down the motorway and that's
probably going to be much the same with this
version.
To start of with there is going to be three diesels - a 1.6-litre one will be the

highlight as far as emissions are
concerned
because that'll be comfortably under 100g/km.

There is also gonna be two 2.0-litre diesels
under around

110 and 120g/km
respectively.
If you're after a petrol, however, there is going to be a good selection there as well. To start off
with there is going to be a 1.5-litre EcoBoost
and, in the future, there is a high chance there is going to be a 1.0-litre EcoBoost
in a car this size as well. Theres also going to be a hybrid version. Now as I mentioned earlier that is
only gonna be in the saloon but that will also give you

sub-100 g/km emissions. There is going to
be
three trim levels that you can choose from. There is going to be Style, Zetec,
and Titanium - there is going to be more detail on what exactly you get with that
as time goes by - but there is also, at the top of the range,
in a few months after the car has been launched, something called a Vignale. That is
going to come

with a little bit more in the way of visual
stuff on the outside and the inside -
a bit more stitching, a bit more chrome, that sort of thing - but Vignale, Ford says is much
more about the experience.
That means that you get much a more personal relationship with your dealer, you get one person that you can
call up

and get in touch. They will come and
collect your car and deliver it back to
you when it comes to being serviced.
Apparently you can also even drop in and have the car washed.
There is going to be the first of these dealers open at the end of the year in London

and more of them at Ford dealerships as
time goes by.

Pricing hasn't been totally nailed down
for this car yet, but we reckon it won't

be a million miles away from the current
car, and that means it is going to start
at about £21,000 and go up, going on
current car, to about £30,000 or so. As time goes on then the Vignale models etc
might add

a little bit on top of that, but not a
huge amount. There'll be more information on that
come the Paris Motor Show in October
so keep an eye on Whatcar.com then for that. We'll also be driving the car
around October as well,
so keep an eye out on Whatcar.com for our full verdict.

title: Five reasons to look forward to the 2015 Ford Mondeo - What Car?
